awd_abstract_narration:
In fields such as oil and gas prospecting, mapping the interior of a planet, or medical imaging, one determines properties of the interior of an object such as the location of oil/gas deposits in the interior of the earth, characterize the interior composition of a planet, or determine if an interior lump in the body is cancerous or not. Since drilling or cutting is often expensive or unfeasible in these situations, these objects are probed by non-invasive methods such as sound waves generated on the boundary of the object. The expectation is that the interior composition of the object will influence the incoming waves and the response wave, also measured only on the boundary of the object, provides a mathematical window into the interior of the object. The principal investigator (PI) will study the mathematics behind this imaging technique. Further, the PI will train graduate students and postdocs in this type of mathematics through mini-courses, seminars, personal conversations and workshops. Some of these students and postdocs will use these skills to solve practical problems for companies exploring for oil, building imaging devices, or involved in remote sensing.

Problems like those described above, but with over-determined data, where the unknown function depends on fewer variables than the data, have received a lot of attention. The PI focuses on the less studied formally determined problems where the unknown function depends on the same number of variables as the data. Such problems, in two or more space dimensions, are harder but very useful in situations where data acquisition is difficult, and their investigation is one of the important challenges in the field. This project will study the following problems in three space dimensions: the fixed angle scattering problem, the backscattering problem, the point source problem, and the incoming spherical wave problem. Recently, using an adaptation of the Bukhgeim-Klibanov method, the PI and his collaborators proved stability for the fixed angle scattering problem for coefficients which are even in one of the variables and proved uniqueness for the problem of recovering a coefficient given data from the point source problem as well as the incoming spherical wave problem. This project aims at further adapting the Bukhgeim-Klibanov method to use Robbiano-Tataru type Carleman estimates and unique continuation arguments to tackle the proposed problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In oil exploration, the preliminary goal is to determine whether there is oil underneath a surface, without drilling holes. Since the density of oil is different from the density of water, rock, and other material present below the surface (we call it the medium), knowing the density at each point of the medium would determine what lies below a surface. One way geophysicists determine the density and other physical properties of the medium below a surface is by probing the medium by sound waves generated by an explosion on the surface (call it the source) and the medium response is measured on the surface by seismograms. The goal is the determination of the density function of the medium from the measurements, on the surface of the medium, of the response of the medium. 

 

The physics of the interaction between the sound waves and the density at different points of the medium is captured by the wave equation with the density function appearing as a coefficient of the wave operator, the medium response represented by the solution of the wave equation, and the source of the explosion as a boundary condition for the solution of the wave equation. The medium response measurements on the surface are a different (from the source) type of boundary values of the solution. So the goal reduces to determining a coefficient of the wave operator, given the source and the surface measurements of the medium response; note the source and the medium response are connected through the wave operator.

 

Our work consists of a theoretical analysis of such problems. In practice, for the same medium, geophysicists collect seismic data from many such experiments, moving the source to different locations on the surface of the medium. We investigate what one can discover about the density function of the medium from the surface measurements of the medium response from just one such experiment. Further, we allow more complicated versions of the model, where the acoustic property of the medium is allowed to be direction dependent (anisotropic), so the acoustic property of the medium is modeled not by a real valued function (the density) but by a matrix valued function (a Riemannian metric). For applications in other areas of Physics and Mathematics, we also consider problems where the acoustic property of the medium is modeled by a space and time dependent matrix valued function (a Lorentzian metric).

 

We show one can distinguish a uniform (constant) medium from a non-uniform medium, using surface measurements of the medium response, coming from just a few (dimension dependent) experiments. Even this seemingly small, non-trivial step was a long open problem. We combine geometrical and topological ideas with techniques from the theory of Partial Differential Equations to obtain the results.
